Michigan Ongoing Health & Safety Training Refresher 2023
Section 3: Prevention & Control of Infectious Disease (Including Immunizations)

Immunizations

Let’s address Immunizations first. Immunizations are an essential part of infectious disease control. Vaccinations allow the body to develop antibodies to resist serious diseases.

The immunization schedules for children, adolescents, and adults developed by the Centers for Disease Control have been adopted by the MIchigan Department of Health and Human Services and Caring for Our Children Guidelines. The link to these schedules can be found in the support material at the end of this chapter.

Let’s discuss why it is so important for child care providers to promote immunization.

  • Best Means of Prevention

    Immunizations are the best means of preventing a large number of harmful childhood diseases.

  • State Law Requirement

    For children participating in group settings, State law requires documentation of vaccines received.

  • Reemergence of Serious Diseases

    In the past decade immunization rates declined. Parents may have been afraid of the side effects of the vaccine or felt their child was safe since the diseases had declined. The sad result of this has been the reemergence of several serious diseases like measles, chicken pox, and pertussis (whooping cough). Child care providers need to encourage parents to have their children vaccinated.
